replication_study.hypothesis: Respondents who belong to the post-secular latent class will be less likely than respondents in the traditional latent class to endorse the statement that humans evolved from earlier species of animals (binary item ‘evolved’).

data_plan.source_type: U.S. General Social Survey (face-to-face / web interview survey)
data_plan.wave_or_subset: 2012, 2014, 2016, 2018 science-module waves (i.e., observations collected AFTER the waves used in the original 2006-2010 study)
data_plan.sample_size: ≈ 3,500 respondents before list-wise deletion; exact N is printed by the script after filters (see replication_result.txt).
data_plan.access_details: Dataset already provided in /app/data/GSSreplication.dta (public-domain GSS data transformed and bundled by Ramljak/Axxe).

qualification.explanation: The dataset contains the identical science-knowledge, science-attitude, and religion items needed to reproduce the latent class indicators and the focal evolution outcome, allowing a clean test of the same theoretical relationship on a new, independent sample of GSS respondents.
qualification.similarity_to_original: Same parent survey (GSS special science module) and identical item wording/coding as described in post_registration.json (‘source’: GSS, ‘variables’: identical science and religion indicators) and in OBrienReplication_OSF_Axxe_20201012.do (lines 52-60 list the identical variables).
qualification.deviation_from_original: Original analysis pooled 2006, 2008, 2010 waves (post_registration.json → data.wave_or_subset). The present dataset restricts to later waves 2012-2018 (see comments at top of .do file, first paragraph), delivering a non-overlapping time-based replication sample.

data_plan.notes: Variables already recoded to numeric Stata codes but still require the cleaning steps replicated in Python. Weight variable (wtss) retained; survey design effects not modeled in focal t-test, matching the Axxe replication approach.

steps: Reproduce variable recoding/cleaning exactly as in Axxe (2020) .do file (binary correctness, scale reversals, missing-value handling).
Perform list-wise deletion on all latent-class indicator variables (as in original).
Estimate a three-class latent class model on the indicator set; if latentpy unavailable, approximate with K-modes clustering.
Label classes heuristically (Traditional = highest Bible literalism, Post-Secular = lowest).
Create binary flag PostsecVsTrad (1 = Post-Secular, 0 = Traditional).
Conduct independent-samples t-test on ‘evolved_clean’ between the two groups.
planned_method.models: Latent Class Analysis with 3 latent classes (or categorical K-modes clustering fallback); independent-samples t-test.
planned_method.outcome_variable: evolved_clean (1 = answered correctly that humans evolved, 0 = answered incorrectly).
planned_method.independent_variables: Latent class membership derived from 19 science, religion, and attitude indicators.
planned_method.control_variables: None for focal t-test (mirrors original simple comparison).
planned_method.tools_software: Python 3.10; pandas, numpy, scipy, latentpy (optional), kmodes (fallback).

planned_estimation_and_test.estimation: Mean difference in endorsement of evolution between classes.

planned_method.missing_data_handling: Listwise deletion on latent-class indicators; respondents with missing outcome removed prior to t-test.
planned_method.inference_criteria: Two-sided p < 0.05; effect must be negative (post-secular mean < traditional mean) to replicate original direction.

files.replication_data/run_replication.py: End-to-end Python script translating Axxe (2020) Stata .do logic. Performs data cleaning, latent-class estimation (or K-modes fallback), class labeling, t-test, and writes human-readable summary to /app/data/replication_result.txt.

codebase.notes: All file IO hard-coded to /app/data to satisfy execution environment rules. Script auto-detects data location and gracefully degrades if latentpy/K-modes unavailable.

analysis.instructions: Inside the container run:  python replication_data/run_replication.py   (or make it the CMD of the Dockerfile). The script prints and saves a text summary including sample sizes, group means, t-statistic, and p-value.
analysis.comparison_metrics: Direction of effect (negative), p-value (<0.05 threshold), and magnitude difference of evolution endorsement relative to original reported 3 percentage-point gap.
